description: From Middle English clenly, clenliche, clanly, from Old English clǣnlīċ (“cleanly, pure, excellent”), equivalent to clean +‎ -ly.

adjectives.description: cleanly (comparative cleanlier or more cleanly, superlative cleanliest or most cleanly)

entries.meaning: Being habitually clean, practising good hygiene.
examples: While his lov'd partner boastful of her hoard,
Displays the cleanly platter on the board;

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Cleansing; fitted to remove moisture; dirt, etc.
examples: With cleanly powder dry their hair.

description: From Middle English clenly, clenli, clenliche, from Old English clǣnlīċe (“cleanly”), equivalent to clean +‎ -ly.

adverbs.description: cleanly (comparative cleanlier or more cleanly, superlative cleanliest or most cleanly)

entries.meaning: Not causing a mess or unnecessary damage.
examples: We agreed to break off our relationship cleanly.
Fortunately, the bullet passed cleanly through your shoulder.
The boy will do well certain : give him grace To have a quick hand and convey things cleanly
